title.rendered: Ageing and Changes in Physical and Mental Health

content.rendered:
Ageing men and women, especially within the age-range of 60 and above contribute greatly to the society. They’re important in the family, volunteering exercises, and for the overall good of everyone. While most of them have good mental health, some of them are at the risk of developing mental ailments. Not to forget the various health conditions these group of people experience. Furthermore as people age, they’re more likely to experience the same symptoms at the same time.

The Problem

Presently, we are having a rapid growth of ageing people. According to research, there’ll be a 22 percent increase of ageing adults in the year 2050. Being more concrete, this is an exponential increase from 1 billion to 2 billion of people older than 60 years. And as we’ve noticed in older people, they’re prone to a number of physical ailments.

It is estimated that over 29 percent of adults aged 60 and above are prone to various kinds of neural disorders. And about 7 percent of disabled ones are related to mental and neural disorders. Shocking to note, these disorders make up about 20 percent of older adults disabled years.

The common type of these disorders found in the age group of 60 and above is either depression or dementia. Which has been known to affect 7 percent of the world’s older people. While 4 percent of the older population are vulnerable to anxiety disorders. 1 percent of the population suffer from substance abuse. While a quarter of the same population die because of self-harm.

The Risk Factors

As a person grows there is a likely tendency to be prone to various mental health problems. Older people are known to be prone to functional disability, especially in their later life. For example, an older person may experience a loss of sensual response in their limbs which make them slow to walk. In this category, such a person would need a long-time care.

Other factors faced by ageing people are loss in socioeconomic status and frequent frustrations. All of these experience, called stressors can result in their isolation. And in such a phase, they’ll need long-term care.

A persons mental health has an impact on either his or her physical health and vice versa. For example, it has been found that older adults with heart diseases are more prone to depression. In addition, when depression is untreated it could lead to fatal outcomes.

Here are a few experiences of ageing people;

  • Verbal abuse
  • Sexual abuse
  • Physical abuse
  • Abandonment
  • Neglect
  • Loss of respect  and,
  • dignity

Prone ailments: Depression and Dementia

Depression

Depression is a mental disease, which causes great suffering. According to Health reports, 8 percent of ageing people are prone to Unipolar depression. This also accounts for 6 percent of disabilities found among this age group. And as we have it in our Health care facilities, depression is most times undertreated or under-diagnosed.

Symptoms of depression found in ageing people are:

  • Diabetes
  • Hypertension
  • Migraine
  • Lung disease

 Dementia

This is simply a loss of memory and it’s quite common among ageing people. It affects thoughts, or capacity to reason clearly, behavior, and overall daily activities. Physicians posits is a normal part in the ageing process. According to estimations, over 55 million people live with dementia; 65 percent of them living in developing countries.

Here are the causes of Dementia:

  • Economic pressures (poverty)
  • Emotional pressures (loss of loved ones and isolation)
  • Physical pressures (excessive physical work)

Therefore this just means that, these particular age-group need all the socioeconomic support as provided by the government.

WHO Participation

Presently, governments and WHO do collaborate with each other in having a sustainable health system so as to promote better mental health with this age-group. And also integrating effective mechanisms into plans and policies of each country.
